sentence.text: Patient 2 is the older brother of Patient 1.
He was recognized to have similar craniofacial features during childhood but without craniosynostosis (Figure 1).
Head shape at age 8 years at time of referral to a craniofacial clinic was described as brachycephaly with retrusion of supraorbital rims and proptosis.
Maxilla was retruded with Class III malocclusion.
Submerged deciduous teeth were documented at age 12 years.
He had bilateral chronic serious otitis media with conductive hearing loss.
At age 7 years, agenesis of the right malleus and incus and fixation of the right stapes was noted at the time of surgical middle ear exploration.
Otoscopy at age 13 years suggested absence of the left incus with continued serous effusion.
He was treated with orthodontics and a combination of LeFort I and LeFort III maxillary osteotomy with distraction and iliac crest bone graft.
As an adult, he was seen for medical genetics evaluation at another center where his height was 188 cm and weight 72.5 kg.
His craniofacies, hands and feet were described as normal.
He has developed a seizure disorder.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and cervical spine showed mild Chiari 1 malformation with a small syrinx at C2.
